title.narrative: IR 1.3: Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH)

description.narrative: IR 1.3: Core Commitments in Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) are met in Refugee camps and host communities, which contributes to Sanitation, Wash And Emergencies, Water. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: PCR1. National institutions provide improved health and neonatal care services and quality early childhood care with a focus on disadvantaged groups.

participating-org.narrative: AMERICA MIDEAST EDUCATION AND TRAINING COMPANY INC

sector.narrative: HSS - Risk informed programming including climate resilience disaster and conflict
Public health emergencies, including disease outbreaks
Sanitation and hygiene - improving services in emergency communities
Sanitation in emergencies - improving sanitation services in communities
WASH in emergencies - institutions (schools, health care facilities, ECD centres) response including menstrual hygiene management
Water supply in emergencies - improving water supply services communities

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: IR 1.3: Core Commitments in WASH are met in Refugee camps and host communities
Number of Emergency affected population (male and female) with access to appropriately designed toilets and sanitation services

target.value: 2014:345,000 refugees (in camps and off camp) and 180,000 affected Jordanians

actual.value: 2014:- Desludging of communal, household and institutional latrines continued in Za'atari, Azraaq, Cyber City and King Abdullah park camps, benefiting an estimated 98,000 people, of which approximately 52,000 were children- maintenance, repair and rehabilitation were carried out on communal WASH blocks

title.narrative: Number of emergency affected population (male and female) provided with access to drinking and domestic water

baseline.value: 130,000 refugees in camps and 468,000 in host communities in 2013

target.value: 2014:345,000 refugees (in camps and off camp) and 180,000 affected Jordanians

actual.value: 2014:- Throughout the year, an estimated 98,000 refugees (including approximately 52,000 children) in Za'atari, Azraaq, Cyber City and King Abdallah park camps were provided with drinking water (35 l/p/d) through the distribution of approximately 4 million litres of treated water per day (120,000 people

title.narrative: Number of people provided with access to solid waste management (cumulative beneficiaries reached)

actual.value: 2014:An average of 800 m3 of solid waste was collected and disposed of on a daily basis from the four camps, benefiting an estimated 98,000 refugees, including an estimated 52,000 children-WASH Block committees were established and these committees assumed responsibility for the operation and maintenanc

title.narrative: Number of Emergency affected population (male and female) provided with access to soap and other hygiene items

target.value: 2014:345,000 refugees (in camps and off camp) and 180,000 affected Jordanians

actual.value: 2014:An estimated 107,000 people benefited from distributions of WASH Non-Food Items (NFIs), including approximately 57,000 children- Soap was distributed to approximately 17,000 households in Za'atari camp on a monthly basis - 36 WASH committees received cleaning kits and monthly hygiene kits which fa

title.narrative: Number of population (male and female) covered through face to face (including HH and Group sessions) hygiene promotion messages

target.value: 2014:345,000 refugees (in camps and off camp) and 180,000 affected Jordanians

actual.value: 2014:An estimated 98,000 people were reached through direct messaging (household visits, campaigns and focus groups) on key hygiene messages, which included approximately 52,000 children in Za'atari, Azraaq, Cyber City and Kind Abdullah Park camps,- in the host communities an additional 10,000 people we

title.narrative: Number of Syrian boys and girls in schools reached with hygiene messages

actual.value: 2014:Approximately 135,628 students were reached with messages on hygiene promotion (including 116,788 students reached in host communities, 15,500 students in Za'atari, 1,340 in Azraq and 2,000 students through EGC schools in coordination with the Education section)

title.narrative: Number of children (girls and boys) provided with access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene facilities in their learning environment and in child friendly spaces

actual.value: 2014:WASH facilities in 164 schools in host communities were rehabilitated which facilitated the practice of key WASH behaviours in the schools which benefitted an estimated 188,000 children

title.narrative: Availability of effective working group coordination mechanism

baseline.value: WASH Working group functional and ToRs developed

target.value: 2015:Formation of a working group for the sector response plan

actual.value: 2014:UNICEF led the coordination of WASH activities with meetings conducted on a monthly basis at a national level, in addition to weekly meetings at camp levels. Some of the key achievements of the coordination are summarised as:- incorporation of key WASH issues in the Regional Refugee and Resilience
